elements.content: A primary-amide-functionalized metal organic framework, {[Zn2(2-BQBG)­(BDC)2]·10H2O} n (1) (in which 2-BQBG = 2,2′-(butane-1,4-diylbis­((quinolin-2-ylmethyl)­azanediyl))­diacetamide and BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate), has been found to be a highly efficient hydrogen-bond-donating (HBD) heterogeneous catalyst for the Friedel–Crafts alkylation of indole with β-nitrostyrenes under mild reaction conditions (catalyst loading: 3 mol %; reaction conditions: 12 h and 35 °C). The catalyst can be easily separated from the reaction mixture by simple filtration for its reuse in four consecutive cycles with very little loss of activity. More importantly, the one-pot room temperature synthesis of 1 from the self-assembly of Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O and 2-BQBG (in CH3OH) and Na2BDC (in H2O) can be easily scaled-up for obtaining multigram quantities in few hours. In order to showcase its versatility, the substrate scope included a variety of substituted indoles and different β-nitrostyrene derivatives forming the desired products in good to high yields. For its catalytic action, a direct proof for the key step in the proposed mechanism, based on the interaction of a primary-amide group in the 2-BQBG ligand with the nitro group of β-nitrostyrene through hydrogen bonding, is provided from the enhancement in fluorescence intensity of 1 upon successive addition of β-nitrostyrene.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are two- and three-dimensional crystalline materials consisting of metal ions or inorganic nodes and polytopic neutral and/or anionic organic ligands or linkers exhibiting rich topological diversity, high surface area, and porosity. On the basis of the careful choice of components, the structure and properties of MOFs can be tuned. This feature, which is achieved through incorporation of desired functionalities into MOFs by tailoring the organic ligands and/or linkers, has allowed their experimental demonstrations of numerous applications, such as gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, proton conductivity, water purification, drug delivery, and heterogeneous catalysis, among others. In particular, the use of various functional groups incorporated through the ligands into the framework has been the key to their application in catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are two- and three-dimensional crystalline materials consisting of metal ions or inorganic nodes and polytopic neutral and/or anionic organic ligands or linkers exhibiting rich topological diversity, high surface area, and porosity. On the basis of the careful choice of components, the structure and properties of MOFs can be tuned. This feature, which is achieved through incorporation of desired functionalities into MOFs by tailoring the organic ligands and/or linkers, has allowed their experimental demonstrations of numerous applications, such as gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, proton conductivity, water purification, drug delivery, and heterogeneous catalysis, among others. In particular, the use of various functional groups incorporated through the ligands into the framework has been the key to their application in catalysis.

elements.content: For our interests in designing new organic ligands and linkers with suitable functional groups for the development of new MOFs and their application in heterogeneous catalysis, we have focused on the biomimetic hydrogen-bond-donating (HBD) catalysts for the bond-forming reactions as an alternative to Lewis acid catalysts. Many research groups have demonstrated the potential of MOFs for catalyzing numerous C–C bond-forming transformations, such as conjugate addition reactions, Diels–Alder reactions, 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reactions, and Friedel–Crafts reactions. In general, homogeneous HBD catalysts containing hydrogen donor sites can significantly undergo self-quenching, which greatly decreases the catalyst activity. Recently, it was shown that incorporation of a hydrogen-bond-donating site into MOFs can help to avoid such self-quenching of the catalyst.

Many research groups have demonstrated the potential of MOFs for catalyzing numerous C-C bond-forming transformations, such as conjugate addition reactions, Diels-Alder reactions, 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reactions, and Friedel-Crafts reactions. In general, homogeneous HBD catalysts containing hydrogen donor sites can significantly undergo self-quenching, which greatly decreases the catalyst activity. Recently, it was shown that incorporation of a hydrogen-bond-donating site into MOFs can help to avoid such self-quenching of the catalyst.

elements.content: The Friedel–Crafts reaction between aromatic compounds and electron-deficient alkenes has been used widely in synthetic organic chemistry. For example, the reaction of indole with β-nitroalkenes, such as β-nitrostyrene, is important and the most widely used reaction toward the synthesis of indole-based alkaloids, such as physostigmine, melatonin analogues, and tryptamine derivatives. Nitroalkenes, being active Michael acceptors, have become very important as a result of the fact that the nitro derivatives can be transformed into amino compounds with a variety of different functionalities. The reaction of unsubstituted indole with β-nitroalkenes is slow compared to that of N-alkylated indole (e.g., 1-methylindole) because of the poor nucleophilicity of indole. For solving this problem, attempts have been made to use various catalysts, such as organocatalysts or metallic catalysts in homogeneous phase and porous heterogeneous catalysts. Thus, a simple, cost-effective, and highly efficient catalyst has been the current target for this organic transformation.

Nitroalkenes, being active Michael acceptors, have become very important as a result of the fact that the nitro derivatives can be transformed into amino compounds with a variety of different functionalities. The reaction of unsubstituted indole with β-nitroalkenes is slow compared to that of N-alkylated indole (e.g., 1-methylindole) because of the poor nucleophilicity of indole. For solving this problem, attempts have been made to use various catalysts, such as organocatalysts or metallic catalysts in homogeneous phase and porous heterogeneous catalysts. Thus, a simple, cost-effective, and highly efficient catalyst has been the current target for this organic transformation.

elements.content: In recent years, numerous efforts have been invested in the development of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts with a hydrogen-bond donor site for the Friedel–Crafts alkylation of indole with nitroalkenes. HBD catalysts activate electrophilic substrates (e.g., nitroalkene) toward nucleophiles (e.g., indole) through hydrogen bonding, which lowers the energy of lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the electrophiles and thus favors a smooth nucleophilic attack. For the synthesis of such HBD MOF catalysts, an extensive use of many urea-, thiourea-, and squaramide-based ligands with incorporated hydrogen-bond donor sites has flooded the literature. These ligands in MOFs activate substrates containing a nitro group through hydrogen bonding toward nucleophilic attack. Urea- and thiourea-incorporated heterogeneous catalysts form a cyclic hydrogen-bonded motif R 2 2(8), whereas squaramide forms an R 2 2(9) motif with a nitro group of substrates (). However, some of procedures reported for such catalysts suffer from high catalyst loading, long reaction time, need of additives, and multistep synthesis of catalyst through postsynthetic modification (PSM) or postsynthetic exchange (PSE) of MOFs, thus limiting their practical applications.

Urea- and thiourea-incorporated heterogeneous catalysts form a cyclic hydrogen-bonded motif R 2 2(8), whereas squaramide forms an R 2 2(9) motif with a nitro group of substrates (). However, some of procedures reported for such catalysts suffer from high catalyst loading, long reaction time, need of additives, and multistep synthesis of catalyst through postsynthetic modification (PSM) or postsynthetic exchange (PSE) of MOFs, thus limiting their practical applications.

elements.content: For developing an efficient catalyst in the Friedel–Crafts reaction, a new ligand, namely, 2,2′-(butane-1,4-diylbis­((quinolin-2-ylmethyl)­azanediyl))­diacetamide (2-BQBG), shown in , has been designed based on the following reasons: (i) each of the two primary-amide functionalities in the ligand plays a key role through coordination of the oxygen atom to a metal center, increasing the acidity of the N–H bond and creating a hydrogen-bond-donating environment, which may facilitate the catalytic reactions; (ii) the primary-amide side arm can form a six-membered cyclic hydrogen-bonded motif R 2 2(6) with a nitro group of substrates, which is more favorable than forming an eight-membered (urea- and thiourea-containing) or nine-membered (squaramide-containing) cyclic hydrogen-bonded motif (the pioneering studies of Etter on the definition of a variety of hydrogen-bonding motifs between −NO2 and −NH2 moieties has partly encouraged us to emphasize this); and (iii) the ligand consists of multiple coordinating groups that are found to be suitable for constructing extended frameworks with a large surface area, also favorable for catalysis. All these points have been summarized for this work in .

All these points have been summarized for this work in .

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of a new MOF with a novel primary-amide-based ligand (2-BQBG, ) (viz., {[Zn2(2-BQBG)­(BDC)2]·10H2O} n (1), where BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) and its catalytic application in the Friedel–Crafts alkylation reaction of indole and β-nitrostyrene under mild reaction conditions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report involving a primary-amide-functionalized MOF as a HBD heterogeneous catalyst. Thus, our work provides insights into the great potential of primary-amide ligand-based MOFs for the design of HBD heterogeneous catalysis.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of a new MOF with a novel primary-amide-based ligand (2-BQBG, ) (viz., {[Zn2(2-BQBG)(BDC)2]⋅10H2O} n  (1), where BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) and its catalytic application in the Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction of indole and β-nitrostyrene under mild reaction conditions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report involving a primary-amide-functionalized MOF as a HBD heterogeneous catalyst. Thus, our work provides insights into the great potential of primary-amide ligand-based MOFs for the design of HBD heterogeneous catalysis.

elements.content: A light-yellow, solid 2-BQBG ligand was obtained from a two-step process in an overall yield of 66%. The first step involves a Schiff base condensation reaction of 2-quinoline carboxaldehyde and 1,4-diaminobutane (in a 2:1 ratio) in CH3OH and the subsequent reduction of the intermediate by sodium borohydride. In the second step, the SN2 reaction between the reduced Schiff base with 2-bromoacetamide in CH3CN (Scheme S1) occurs. Its high purity was confirmed by NMR and MS data as well as a sharp melting point. The FT-IR, 1H and 13C NMR, and MS (LD-TOF) spectra of 2-BQBG are reported in Figures S1–S4 of Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

A light-yellow, solid 2-BQBG ligand was obtained from a two-step process in an overall yield of 66%. The first step involves a Schiff base condensation reaction of 2-quinoline carboxaldehyde and 1,4-diaminobutane (in a 2:1 ratio) in CH3OH and the subsequent reduction of the intermediate by sodium borohydride. In the second step, the SN2 reaction between the reduced Schiff base with 2-bromoacetamide in CH3CN (Scheme S1) occurs. Its high purity was confirmed by NMR and MS data as well as a sharp melting point. The FT-IR, 1H and 13C NMR, and MS (LD-TOF) spectra of 2-BQBG are reported in Figures S1-S4 of Supporting Information.

elements.content: Compound 1 was isolated in 79% yield from a three-component self-assembly reaction of Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O, 2-BQBG, and Na2BDC in a 2:1:2 ratio under ambient conditions. Its formula and phase purity were obtained by elemental analysis, TGA, FT-IR spectroscopy, and X-ray diffraction (single crystal and powder) analysis. In the FTIR spectrum of 1 (Figure S5), a strong peak at 1676 cm–1 is observed for the carbonyl group in 2-BQBG, whereas those at 1580 and 1376 cm–1 correspond to asymmetric and symmetric stretching frequencies for the carboxylate groups of BDC, respectively. These values with a difference of 204 cm–1 for the carboxylate groups are indicative of bis­(monodentate) binding of BDC to Zn­(II) as is found in its crystal structure (vide infra). A clear match between the simulated (generated from the single-crystal data) and experimental PXRD patterns of 1 (Figure S6) proves that the single crystals (from the layering method) and bulk material (from the room temperature synthesis) are the same. It further confirms the phase purity of 1. On the basis of the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), the first weight loss (between 30 and 250 °C) of 15.8% (ca. 16.0%) corresponds to ten lattice water molecules, and the second weight loss (between 250 and 500 °C) of ∼53% (ca. 53.4%) corresponds to ligand (2-BQBG) and linkers (BDC). This result clearly shows the strong hydrogen bonding of lattice water molecules with amide functionality as well as framework stability up to 250 °C. The TGA curve of the activated 1 (obtained by heating at 120 °C under vacuum for 5 h) does not show any weight loss up to 250 °C, indicating the absence of lattice water molecules (Figure S7). Furthermore, the PXRD pattern for the activated 1 (Figure S6) matches with that of 1, indicating the retention of its structural integrity upon the loss of lattice solvent.

A clear match between the simulated (generated from the single-crystal data) and experimental PXRD patterns of 1 (Figure S6) proves that the single crystals (from the layering method) and bulk material (from the room temperature synthesis) are the same. It further confirms the phase purity of 1. elements.content: On the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P 1 and has a 2D coordination polymer structure. One Zn­(II) ion, one BDC, half of the 2-BQBG ligand, and five lattice water molecules are present in the asymmetric unit. Each Zn­(II) center adopts a pentacoordinated square pyramidal geometry, based on the value of the τ parameter, 0.194 (Figure S8, left), with an N2O3 environment and is surrounded by one oxygen and two nitrogen atoms of the 2-BQBG ligand and two carboxyl oxygen atoms from two different BDC linkers ( (left) and Figure S8 (right)). The Zn–N1(quinoline) distance (2.129(5) Å) is shorter than the Zn–N2(alkyl) distance (2.154(5) Å). The two Zn–Ocarb distances are found to be almost similar, Zn–O2 (2.007(4) Å) and Zn–O4 (1.954(4) Å), and are in a similar range reported in the literature. Crystallographic data along with structure refinement parameters and selected bond distances and angles are summarized in Tables S1 and S2, respectively. Two Zn­(II) centers connected by the BDC linker are separated by 10.950 Å, whereas those connected by the spanning ligand (2-BQBG) are separated by 8.164 Å. On the basis of this connectivity, six Zn centers that form a cavity with a dimension of 19.023 × 6.517 Å (distances between two BDC linkers on opposite sides) adopt a chair conformation, extending to a trans-decaline type 2D polymer structure (, right, and Figure S9). Two 2D sheets in 1 are further connected via moderate π–π interactions between the quinoline rings (centroid–centroid distances are 3.719 and 3.808 Å) to form a 3D supramolecular assembly (, left). Furthermore, as shown in (right), the topological analysis of 1 reveals that it has a uninodal 3-connected net (topology: hcb and Schläfli point symbol: {63}).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

On the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P 1 and has a 2D coordination polymer structure. One Zn(II) ion, one BDC, half of the 2-BQBG ligand, and five lattice water molecules are present in the asymmetric unit. Each Zn(II) center adopts a pentacoordinated square pyramidal geometry, based on the value of the τ parameter, 0.194 (Figure S8, left), with an N2O3 environment and is surrounded by one oxygen and two nitrogen atoms of the 2-BQBG ligand and two carboxyl oxygen atoms from two different BDC linkers ( (left) and Figure S8 (right)). The Zn-N1(quinoline) distance (2.129(5) Å) is shorter than the Zn-N2(alkyl) distance (2.154(5) Å). The two Zn-Ocarb distances are found to be almost similar, Zn-O2 (2.007(4) Å) and Zn-O4 (1.954(4) Å), and are in a similar range reported in the literature. Crystallographic data along with structure refinement parameters and selected bond distances and angles are summarized in Tables S1 and S2, respectively. Two Zn(II) centers connected by the BDC linker are separated by 10.950 Å, whereas those connected by the spanning ligand (2-BQBG) are separated by 8.164 Å. On the basis of this connectivity, six Zn centers that form a cavity with a dimension of 19.023 × 6.517 Å (distances between two BDC linkers on opposite sides) adopt a chair conformation, extending to a trans-decaline type 2D polymer structure (, right, and Figure S9). Two 2D sheets in 1 are further connected via moderate π-π interactions between the quinoline rings (centroid-centroid distances are 3.719 and 3.808 Å) to form a 3D supramolecular assembly (, left). Furthermore, as shown in  (right), the topological analysis of 1 reveals that it has a uninodal 3-connected net (topology: hcb and Schläfli point symbol: {63}).

elements.content: Prior to its use, 1 was fully activated under vacuum (120 °C, 5 h) to remove the lattice water molecules and provide accessible active sites for substrates. For assessing the catalytic activity of 1 as a solid heterogeneous catalyst in the Friedel–Crafts reaction of indole with β-nitrostyrene, the formation of product was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Both 1H NMR spectra and the relevant calculation for the conversion of this transformation by catalyst 1 are presented in Figure S10. In order to establish the optimized reaction conditions, the catalytic performance of 1 was assessed in the presence of various solvents as well as without solvent at room temperature (27 °C) using 3 mol % (2.8 mg) of 1 for 24 h (, entries 1–6). The reaction rate was found to be solvent dependent in the following order with respect to conversion: dichloromethane (83%) > chloroform (62%) > methanol (60%) > acetonitrile (26%) > toluene (12%). Using dichloromethane as the solvent, the reaction was then performed with an increase in temperature to 35 °C to obtain 100% conversion in 24 h (, entry 7). On the other hand, the reaction was found to be time dependent in that a significant decrease in the conversion was observed for less time (, entries 8–14). A plot of % conversion vs time presented in Figure S11 depicts this trend. Thus, the optimized conditions were found to be as follows: 3 mol % catalyst, CH2Cl2, 35 °C, and 12 h.
elements.clean_text:
Catalysis Studies

Prior to its use, 1 was fully activated under vacuum (120 °C, 5 h) to remove the lattice water molecules and provide accessible active sites for substrates. For assessing the catalytic activity of 1 as a solid heterogeneous catalyst in the Friedel-Crafts reaction of indole with β-nitrostyrene, the formation of product was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Both 1H NMR spectra and the relevant calculation for the conversion of this transformation by catalyst 1 are presented in Figure S10. In order to establish the optimized reaction conditions, the catalytic performance of 1 was assessed in the presence of various solvents as well as without solvent at room temperature (27 °C) using 3 mol % (2.8 mg) of 1 for 24 h (, entries 1-6). The reaction rate was found to be solvent dependent in the following order with respect to conversion: dichloromethane (83%) > chloroform (62%) > methanol (60%) > acetonitrile (26%) > toluene (12%). Using dichloromethane as the solvent, the reaction was then performed with an increase in temperature to 35 °C to obtain 100% conversion in 24 h (, entry 7). On the other hand, the reaction was found to be time dependent in that a significant decrease in the conversion was observed for less time (, entries 8-14). A plot of % conversion vs time presented in Figure S11 depicts this trend. Thus, the optimized conditions were found to be as follows: 3 mol % catalyst, CH2Cl2, 35 °C, and 12 h.

Entries 1–14 were performed using catalyst 1. Entries 15 and 16 were performed using catalyst 1a and 1b, respectively. Entries 17–19 were performed in the presence of 2-BQBG, Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O, and H2BDC, respectively. Entry 20 was carried out without any catalyst.

The catalytic activity was also compared under identical conditions without 1 and each component used for making 1 (i.e., Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O, 2-BQBG, and H2BDC, , entries 17–20). There was no reaction at all in the absence of catalyst, whereas a very low conversion (5.6%) in the presence of H2BDC was observed. With 2-BQBG, a conversion of 29% was observed after 12 h. The improved activity of 1 suggests that it prevents primary-amide self-aggregation, which is likely responsible for the sluggish activity of the free 2-BQBG ligand. This clearly shows the importance of coordination of the carbonyl group of 2-BQBG to the Zn­(II) center, promoting the increase in the acidity of the N–H bond and making the hydrogen-bond-donating environment more favorable (vide supra). In order to support our hypothesis, we have made two more derivatives of 1 in 77–79% yield, following its synthesis procedure: one with a −C­(O)­NEt2 group to show the effect of N–H groups ({[Zn2(2-Et2BQBG)­(BDC)2]·4H2O} n (1a) (where 2-Et2BQBG = 2,2′-(butane-1,4-diylbis­((quinolin-2-ylmethyl)­azanediyl))­bis­(N,N-diethylacetamide)) and the other with a pyridyl group to show the effect of the carbonyl group ({[Zn2(2-QPBN)­(BDC)2]·7H2O} n (1b) (where 2-QPBN = N′,N″-bis­(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-N′,N″-bis­(quinolin-2-ylmethyl)­butane-1,4-dimine) (Scheme 2 and Figures S12 and S13). Under the same catalysis conditions, only 11 and 10% conversions were obtained for 1a and 1b, respectively (, entries 15 and 16; Figures S14 and S15). This observation unequivocally confirms the novelty of the primary-amide groups in 1. On the other hand, only 10% of product formation was observed using Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O (Figure S16).
elements.clean_text: The catalytic activity was also compared under identical conditions without 1 and each component used for making 1 (i.e., Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O, 2-BQBG, and H2BDC, , entries 17-20). There was no reaction at all in the absence of catalyst, whereas a very low conversion (5.6%) in the presence of H2BDC was observed. With 2-BQBG, a conversion of 29% was observed after 12 h. The improved activity of 1 suggests that it prevents primary-amide self-aggregation, which is likely responsible for the sluggish activity of the free 2-BQBG ligand. This clearly shows the importance of coordination of the carbonyl group of 2-BQBG to the Zn(II) center, promoting the increase in the acidity of the N-H bond and making the hydrogen-bond-donating environment more favorable (vide supra). In order to support our hypothesis, we have made two more derivatives of 1 in 77-79% yield, following its synthesis procedure: one with a -C(O)NEt2 group to show the effect of N-H groups ({[Zn2(2-Et2BQBG)(BDC)2]⋅4H2O} n  (1a) (where 2-Et2BQBG = 2,2'-(butane-1,4-diylbis((quinolin-2-ylmethyl)azanediyl))bis(N,N-diethylacetamide)) and the other with a pyridyl group to show the effect of the carbonyl group ({[Zn2(2-QPBN)(BDC)2]⋅7H2O} n  (1b) (where 2-QPBN = N',N"-bis(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-N',N"-bis(quinolin-2-ylmethyl)butane-1,4-dimine) (Scheme 2 and Figures S12 and S13). Under the same catalysis conditions, only 11 and 10% conversions were obtained for 1a and 1b, respectively (, entries 15 and 16; Figures S14 and S15). This observation unequivocally confirms the novelty of the primary-amide groups in 1. On the other hand, only 10% of product formation was observed using Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O (Figure S16).

elements.content: On the basis of the results presented in and discussed above, the substrate scope for 1 with indole and various β-nitrostyrene derivatives was expanded under the optimized reaction conditions (). As expected, β-nitrostyrenes containing electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups could undergo the desired transformation to yield the corresponding alkylated product with satisfactory conversions (Figures S17 and S18).

Determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

Number of moles of product per mole of the catalyst.

Next, the substituents on the indolyl scaffold were also considered (). The catalytic efficiency of 1 varied significantly for differently substituted indoles. A slight decrease in yield (95%) for 2-methylindole is due to the steric factor. In order to prove this point, the 2-phenyl-substituted substrate was used, and the yield was further reduced to 88%. The electron-rich indoles, such as 5-methyl-indole and 5-methoxy-indole, resulted in the respective products in 100% yield. This is consistent with the fact that electron-donating methyl or methoxy groups facilitate activation of the indole ring toward the nucleophilic attack. On the other hand, an electron-withdrawing group bearing indole, such as 5-chloro-indole, results in 72% yield of the corresponding product. More importantly, N-alkylated indole gave a dramatically decreased yield (41%) versus the free indole. This result clearly supports our proposed mechanism (discussed below), validating an interaction of N–H group with the catalyst (Figure S19). Overall, these results demonstrate that 1 is a heterogeneous, efficient, and recyclable catalyst for the Friedel–Crafts reaction.

Compared to the MOFs reported in the literature, which act as HBD catalysts for this kind of reaction, the efficiency of catalyst 1 is noteworthy () in terms of reaction time, catalyst loading, solvent, temperature, yield, and recyclability (vide infra). A urea-derived postmodified 3D MOF, Cr-MIL-101-UR3, boosted the reaction yield up to 93% with 15 mol % catalyst in 24 h at 60 °C (solvent: acetonitrile). Another hydrogen-bond-donating squaramide moiety incorporated in a UiO-67 MOF is also inferior to catalyst 1, even after the use of deuterated solvents. Very recently, a urea-functionalized Cu­(II) 2D MOF synthesized in a solvothermal manner catalyzed this reaction up to 98% yield at 60 °C in 18 h (solvent: acetonitrile). Furthermore, using a high loading (22 mol %) of a Zn­(II) 3D MOF of 4,4′-ureylene–benzene dicarboxylate, about 90% product was obtained (toluene/24 h/60 °C). Similarly, a postsynthetic exchanged urea-functionalized Cu­(II) MOF by Cohen et al. afforded good yield (conditions: 5 mol % catalyst, 24 h at 50 °C in chloroform). Scheidt et al. employed a large amount of Lewis acid (trimethylsilyl chloride, 18 mol %) to enhance the catalytic activity of urea-based Zn­(II) MOF (NU-GRH-1) to get 98% yield (conditions: 3 mol % catalyst, 4 h at 60 °C and toluene-d 8 as solvent). Furthermore, catalyst 1 is synthesized from readily available and cheap starting materials under ambient conditions, providing added advantages over other expensive catalysts.

A leaching experiment for 1 was performed to prove its heterogeneous nature in the reaction between indole and β-nitrostyrene. As shown in Figure S11, the progress of reaction was measured after 1 h, and then, 1 was removed via filtration. Upon following the progress of reaction for another 11 h, it was evident that the removal of catalyst from the reaction mixture halted the formation of product. Thus, 1 is needed for the promotion of this reaction. Additionally, after the separation of 1 from the reaction, the filtrate was evaporated to dryness to determine the amount of zinc in it by EDX. There was no Zn detected (Figure S20). These results clearly indicate that the active species is not leached into product, which is strong evidence for the heterogeneous nature of the reaction.

elements.content: One of the advantages of heterogeneous catalysts is their reusability. On the basis of the performance of 1 under the optimized reaction conditions up to four cycles, its reusability has been found to be very good with very little loss in its activity (Figure S21). During the recycling of 1, its loss actually caused a slight decrease in yield. Comparing the PXRD patterns of fresh and recovered catalyst, it is clear that 1 does not lose its crystallinity during the reaction (Figure S22). Furthermore, FT-IR spectra and solid-state UV–visible spectra of fresh and recovered catalyst (after four cycles) showed no significant changes (Figure S23).

elements.content: Its high catalytic activity can be explained through a proposed mechanistic cycle, where the ligand containing a primary-amide side arm of 1 forms a six-member cyclic hydrogen-bonded motif R 2 2(6) with a nitro group of substrates. This is more favorable than R 2 2(8) or R 2 2(9) cyclic hydrogen-bonded motif formed by urea/thiourea and squaramide-based catalysts, respectively. In addition, 1 has two primary-amide functionalities, which increases the rate of reaction. In the catalytic process, it is assumed that the primary-amide group interacts with the nitro group of the β-nitrostyrene through hydrogen bonding, increasing the electrophilic character of the aliphatic carbon atom and thus favoring the attack from the indole. Similarly, the interaction of an indole (N–H group) with 1 not only increases the nucleophilicity but also brings two substrates efficiently close for the formation of the alkylated product (). In order to support the mechanism, we studied the interaction of β-nitrostyrene with 1 through fluorescence spectroscopy. A finely ground sample of 1 was used for facilitating close contact between the host framework and β-nitrostyrene in the sensing experiment. For investigating its luminescent properties, 2 mg of 1 was well-dispersed in dichloromethane (2 mL) placed in a cuvette by stirring for 10 min. To the stable suspension of 1, a freshly prepared β-nitrostyrene solution (1 mM in dichloromethane) was incrementally added. As shown in b, 1 shows enhancement in fluorescence (at 396 nm) upon successive addition of a β-nitrostyrene (20 μL each time) solution (λex= 315 nm). However, an incremental addition of indole to 1 did not show such noticeable change in intensity (Figure S24).

elements.content: In summary, we demonstrated the novelty of a MOF {[Zn2(2-BQBG)­(BDC)2]·10H2O} n (1) based on a spanning ligand with primary-amide groups, in hydrogen-bond-donating heterogeneous catalysis. Its performance in the Friedel–Crafts alkylation of indoles with various β-nitrostyrenes was found to be much better than other heterogeneous catalysts reported so far in the literature. In particular, an improvement in its catalyst loading over MOFs with secondary amide groups (3 vs 15 mol %, respectively) supported the importance of binding of the primary-amide oxygen atom with Zn, enhancing the acidity of N–H bonds to create a stronger hydrogen-bond-donating environment in the catalysis process. Its broad substrate scope included 6 substituted indoles and 11 substituted β-nitrostyrenes (2-, 3-, or 4-substituted with both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups). Moreover, the loss of activity of 1 is very little after four consecutive cycles. On the basis of two derivatives of catalyst 1, the importance of the primary-amide groups in it was further shown through drastic decrease in product yields. For its catalytic action, a direct proof for the key step in the proposed mechanismthe interaction of a primary-amide group in the 2-BQBG ligand with the nitro group of β-nitrostyrene through hydrogen bondingwas provided from the enhancement in fluorescence intensity of 1 upon successive addition of β-nitrostyrene. As a result of the combined contributions of the ordered 2D structure and highly accessible catalytic active sites, this work with catalyst 1 therefore not only depicts MOFs as a new type of multifunctional catalyst but also provides a new perspective for developing highly efficient and robust heterogeneous-catalyst-promoting reactions via a hydrogen-bond-donating functionality. Further studies toward the design and synthesis of more rigid primary-amide-based MOF catalysts are underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we demonstrated the novelty of a MOF {[Zn2(2-BQBG)(BDC)2]⋅10H2O} n  (1) based on a spanning ligand with primary-amide groups, in hydrogen-bond-donating heterogeneous catalysis. Its performance in the Friedel-Crafts alkylation of indoles with various β-nitrostyrenes was found to be much better than other heterogeneous catalysts reported so far in the literature. In particular, an improvement in its catalyst loading over MOFs with secondary amide groups (3 vs 15 mol %, respectively) supported the importance of binding of the primary-amide oxygen atom with Zn, enhancing the acidity of N-H bonds to create a stronger hydrogen-bond-donating environment in the catalysis process. Its broad substrate scope included 6 substituted indoles and 11 substituted β-nitrostyrenes (2-, 3-, or 4-substituted with both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups). Moreover, the loss of activity of 1 is very little after four consecutive cycles. On the basis of two derivatives of catalyst 1, the importance of the primary-amide groups in it was further shown through drastic decrease in product yields. For its catalytic action, a direct proof for the key step in the proposed mechanismthe interaction of a primary-amide group in the 2-BQBG ligand with the nitro group of β-nitrostyrene through hydrogen bondingwas provided from the enhancement in fluorescence intensity of 1 upon successive addition of β-nitrostyrene. As a result of the combined contributions of the ordered 2D structure and highly accessible catalytic active sites, this work with catalyst 1 therefore not only depicts MOFs as a new type of multifunctional catalyst but also provides a new perspective for developing highly efficient and robust heterogeneous-catalyst-promoting reactions via a hydrogen-bond-donating functionality. Further studies toward the design and synthesis of more rigid primary-amide-based MOF catalysts are underway in our laboratory.

elements.content: All chemicals and solvents that were obtained from commercial sources were used without further purification. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. 1H and 13C NMR spectra of 2-BQBD and 2-BQBG were obtained in CDCl3 at 25 °C on a Bruker ARX-400 spectrometer, where chemical shifts are reported relative to the residual solvent signals. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out from 25 to 500 °C (at a heating rate of 10 °C/min) under a dinitrogen atmosphere on a Shimadzu DTG-60H instrument. The elemental analysis (C, H, N) was carried out using a Leco TruSpec Micro analyzer. FT-IR spectra were measured in the 4000–400 cm–1 range on a PerkinElmer Spectrum I spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Solid state UV–vis spectra were recorded on an Agilent Technologies Cary series (Cary 5000) UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer. Melting points were determined with a Büchi M-565. For catalyst leaching during the reaction, the amount of Zn was estimated by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX, HORIBA EX-250, 15 kV). Powder XRD data were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer, which was described earlier from this laboratory, with a 2-theta range between 5 to 50° with a scanning speed of 2° per minute with a 0.01° step. For the single crystal X-ray diffraction study, see details in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods

All chemicals and solvents that were obtained from commercial sources were used without further purification. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. 1H and 13C NMR spectra of 2-BQBD and 2-BQBG were obtained in CDCl3 at 25 °C on a Bruker ARX-400 spectrometer, where chemical shifts are reported relative to the residual solvent signals. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out from 25 to 500 °C (at a heating rate of 10 °C/min) under a dinitrogen atmosphere on a Shimadzu DTG-60H instrument. The elemental analysis (C, H, N) was carried out using a Leco TruSpec Micro analyzer. FT-IR spectra were measured in the 4000-400 cm-1 range on a PerkinElmer Spectrum I spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Solid state UV-vis spectra were recorded on an Agilent Technologies Cary series (Cary 5000) UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer. Melting points were determined with a Büchi M-565. For catalyst leaching during the reaction, the amount of Zn was estimated by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX, HORIBA EX-250, 15 kV). Powder XRD data were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer, which was described earlier from this laboratory, with a 2-theta range between 5 to 50° with a scanning speed of 2° per minute with a 0.01° step. For the single crystal X-ray diffraction study, see details in the Supporting Information.

2-BQBG is prepared in two steps, where N,N′-bis­(quinolin-2-ylmethyl)­butane-1,4-diamine, 2-BQBD, is an intermediate.

Step 1, Synthesis of 2-BQBD: To a methanolic solution of 2-quinolinecarboxaldehyde (3.14 g, 20 mmol; 10 mL of methanol) placed in a 50 mL two-neck round-bottomed flask (RBF) under a dinitrogen atmosphere, 1,4-diaminobutane (1 mL, 10 mmol) was added at room temperature in a dropwise manner. The mixture was stirred for 4 h, and the resulting yellow solution was then reacted with an excess of sodium borohydride (1.14 g, 1.5 equiv) at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred further for another 6 h. A light-yellow semisolid was isolated from the reaction mixture by extraction with chloroform followed by drying with anhydrous MgSO4 and removal of solvent under vacuum. Yield: 3.53 g (96%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ ppm): δ 8.01–8.08 (4H, m), 7.75 (2H, d), 7.66 (2H, d), 7.43 (4H, m), 4.06 (4H, s), 2.70 (4H, m), 1.63 (4H, m). Selected FT-IR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3350 (br), 2936 (m), 2856 (m), 1595 (s), 1573 (s), 1474 (m), 1438 (m), 1310 (m), 1119 (m), 1050 (s), 1001 (s), 763 (s), 635 (m).

2-BQBG is prepared in two steps, where N,N'-bis(quinolin-2-ylmethyl)butane-1,4-diamine, 2-BQBD, is an intermediate.

Step 1, Synthesis of 2-BQBD: To a methanolic solution of 2-quinolinecarboxaldehyde (3.14 g, 20 mmol; 10 mL of methanol) placed in a 50 mL two-neck round-bottomed flask (RBF) under a dinitrogen atmosphere, 1,4-diaminobutane (1 mL, 10 mmol) was added at room temperature in a dropwise manner. The mixture was stirred for 4 h, and the resulting yellow solution was then reacted with an excess of sodium borohydride (1.14 g, 1.5 equiv) at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred further for another 6 h. A light-yellow semisolid was isolated from the reaction mixture by extraction with chloroform followed by drying with anhydrous MgSO4 and removal of solvent under vacuum. Yield: 3.53 g (96%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ ppm): δ 8.01-8.08 (4H, m), 7.75 (2H, d), 7.66 (2H, d), 7.43 (4H, m), 4.06 (4H, s), 2.70 (4H, m), 1.63 (4H, m). Selected FT-IR peaks (KBr, cm-1): 3350 (br), 2936 (m), 2856 (m), 1595 (s), 1573 (s), 1474 (m), 1438 (m), 1310 (m), 1119 (m), 1050 (s), 1001 (s), 763 (s), 635 (m).

elements.content: Step 2: To a solution of 2-BQBD (740 mg, 2 mmol; 10 mL of dry acetonitrile) placed in a 50 mL RBF, solid K2CO3 (5.52 g, 40 mmol) was added through a funnel, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min under a N2 atmosphere. Subsequently, the dropwise addition of 2-bromoacetamide (555 mg, 4 mmol; dry 15 mL of acetonitrile) to it was carried out. The mixture was refluxed for 12 h, and it was cooled to room temperature and filtered through a G-4 crucible to collect the liquid phase (2 × 10 mL of methanol was used to wash the solid). A solid residue that was obtained upon evaporation of solvents was redissolved in dry methanol. After removal of redundant K2CO3 and KBr (byproduct) via filtration, methanol was evaporated under vacuum to get an oily substance. The desired product as a light-yellow solid was obtained by dissolving the oily substance in 10 mL of CHCl3 at 0 °C followed by filtration and evaporation of the solvent. Yield: 695 mg (72%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ ppm): 8.12 (2H, d), 7.99 (2H, d), 7.82 (2H, d), 7.72 (2H, t), 7.55 (2H, t) 7.35 (2H, d), 3.90 (4H, s), 3.19 (4H, s), 2.56 (4H, m), 1.48 (4H, m). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3, δ ppm): 25.00, 55.61, 58.47, 61.71, 120.77, 126.52, 127.33, 127.65, 128.98, 129.82, 136.79, 147.71, 159.05, 174.73. Selected FT-IR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3375 (s), 3182 (m), 2943 (m), 1654 (s), 1590 (m), 1405 (m), 1342 (m), 1121 (m), 989 (m), 757 (m), 544 (w). M.P.: 162–164 °C. MS (LD-TOF): m/z calcd for [(2-BQBG)­K]+, 523.221; found, 523.222.

2-BQBG is prepared in two steps, where N,N′-bis­(quinolin-2-ylmethyl)­butane-1,4-diamine, 2-BQBD, is an intermediate.

Step 1, Synthesis of 2-BQBD: To a methanolic solution of 2-quinolinecarboxaldehyde (3.14 g, 20 mmol; 10 mL of methanol) placed in a 50 mL two-neck round-bottomed flask (RBF) under a dinitrogen atmosphere, 1,4-diaminobutane (1 mL, 10 mmol) was added at room temperature in a dropwise manner. The mixture was stirred for 4 h, and the resulting yellow solution was then reacted with an excess of sodium borohydride (1.14 g, 1.5 equiv) at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred further for another 6 h. A light-yellow semisolid was isolated from the reaction mixture by extraction with chloroform followed by drying with anhydrous MgSO4 and removal of solvent under vacuum. Yield: 3.53 g (96%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ ppm): δ 8.01–8.08 (4H, m), 7.75 (2H, d), 7.66 (2H, d), 7.43 (4H, m), 4.06 (4H, s), 2.70 (4H, m), 1.63 (4H, m). Selected FT-IR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3350 (br), 2936 (m), 2856 (m), 1595 (s), 1573 (s), 1474 (m), 1438 (m), 1310 (m), 1119 (m), 1050 (s), 1001 (s), 763 (s), 635 (m).

Step 2: To a solution of 2-BQBD (740 mg, 2 mmol; 10 mL of dry acetonitrile) placed in a 50 mL RBF, solid K2CO3 (5.52 g, 40 mmol) was added through a funnel, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min under a N2 atmosphere. Subsequently, the dropwise addition of 2-bromoacetamide (555 mg, 4 mmol; dry 15 mL of acetonitrile) to it was carried out. The mixture was refluxed for 12 h, and it was cooled to room temperature and filtered through a G-4 crucible to collect the liquid phase (2 × 10 mL of methanol was used to wash the solid). A solid residue that was obtained upon evaporation of solvents was redissolved in dry methanol. After removal of redundant K2CO3 and KBr (byproduct) via filtration, methanol was evaporated under vacuum to get an oily substance. The desired product as a light-yellow solid was obtained by dissolving the oily substance in 10 mL of CHCl3 at 0 °C followed by filtration and evaporation of the solvent. Yield: 695 mg (72%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, δ ppm): 8.12 (2H, d), 7.99 (2H, d), 7.82 (2H, d), 7.72 (2H, t), 7.55 (2H, t) 7.35 (2H, d), 3.90 (4H, s), 3.19 (4H, s), 2.56 (4H, m), 1.48 (4H, m). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3, δ ppm): 25.00, 55.61, 58.47, 61.71, 120.77, 126.52, 127.33, 127.65, 128.98, 129.82, 136.79, 147.71, 159.05, 174.73. Selected FT-IR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3375 (s), 3182 (m), 2943 (m), 1654 (s), 1590 (m), 1405 (m), 1342 (m), 1121 (m), 989 (m), 757 (m), 544 (w). M.P.: 162–164 °C. MS (LD-TOF): m/z calcd for [(2-BQBG)­K]+, 523.221; found, 523.222.

Synthesis of {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(2-BQBG)­(BDC)<sub>2</sub>]·10H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Using a 10 mL RBF, Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O (22.7 mg, 0.10 mmol) and 2-BQBG (25 mg, 0.05 mmol) were dissolved in CH3OH (3 mL) and disodium-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (17 mg, 0.10 mmol; 2 mL of water) was subsequently added, leading to the formation of a white precipitate. After the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h, an off-white solid was isolated in dry form by washing it with methanol under vacuum. Yield: 44 mg (79%). Anal calcd (%) for C44H60N6O20Zn2 (MW = 1123.7): calcd C, 47.03; H, 5.38; N, 7.48. Found: C, 46.70; H, 5.73; N, 7.69. Selected FT-IR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3350 (br), 1676 (s), 1580 (s), 1376 (s), 1135 (m), 1202 (w), 826 (m), 801 (m), 744 (s), 689 (s). In a thin test tube, single crystals of 1 were grown as follows: a clear solution of Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O (9 mg, 0.041 mmol) and 2-BQBG (10 mg, 0.020 mmol) dissolved in 0.8 mL of C2H5OH/H2O (1:1, v/v) was layered with a solution of disodium-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (6.6 mg, 0.041 mmol) in 0.8 mL of H2O, keeping a middle layer of 0.2 mL of C2H5OH/H2O (1:1, v/v). Colorless needle shaped crystals that were obtained after 4 days were found to be suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction.

General Protocol Used for the Friedel–Crafts Reaction

Indole (18 mg, 0.15 mmol), β-nitrostyrene (15 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 3 mol % (2.8 mg) of 1 were added to 200 μL of CH2Cl2 in a 5 mL glass screw cap vial. The reaction mixture was stirred at 35 °C for 12 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, it was filtered and washed with 0.5 mL CH2Cl2, and solvent was evaporated under vacuum to get a dry product. To this, 400 μL of CDCl3 was added for 1H NMR analysis. The reaction was monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy via the integration of the α-vinyl and β-vinyl protons of β-nitrostyrene (δ 8.01–8.06 ppm) and the resulting aliphatic proton of the product 3-(2-nitro 1-phenylethyl)-1H-indole (δ 4.92–5.25 ppm). In order to perform the catalyst recycling experiments, the used catalyst (separated by centrifugation and filtration) was washed with MeOH and dried under vacuum. It was then reused for the next run of the reaction as described above.
